Expectation1: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation1: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Story: The salon was already humming with nervous energy when the bride and her entourage swept in, twenty minutes early. I put on my warmest smile, ushering them to their seats, offering tea, and listening to their anxious chatter about the schedule. My hands moved automatically, sectioning hair, but my mind was elsewhere. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from Sister Agnes: a parishioner needed to see me, urgently, about a crisis of faith. As a nun, I was expected to be present, to listen, to offer comfort and guidance. But as a hairdresser, I was expected to stay, to calm the bride, to make her feel beautiful and cared for on her big day. The weight of both worlds pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each expecting me to be wholly theirs. I felt my heart race, torn between the sacred duty of spiritual care and the immediate, tangible needs of the women before me. I glanced at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away, and wondered how I could possibly be enough for both.
